THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT DISCLAIMS ALL WARRANTIES AND LIABILITIES REGARDING THIRD PARTY SOFTWARE, IF PRESENT IN THE SOFTWARE, AND DISTRIBUTES IT "AS IS."

messages.message: This InterSpec Software was developed with funds from the Science and Technology Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security.

message.div: InterSpec is a product of Sandia National Laboratories (SNL) Technical ReachBack (TRB) team, funded by the Science and Technology Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security. Feedback, bug reports, testing, and suggestions for improvement have been provided by many members of the TRB team, as well as the wider gamma spectroscopy community. The primary developers of InterSpec are: Ethan Chan, William Johnson, and Christian Morte, with extensive additional support provided by Noel Nachtigal and Edward Walsh.

InterSpec uses a number of open-source libraries and publicly available resources, including:
Wt a C++ library for web development.
InterSpec uses Wt extensively to render the HTML based GUI, to facilitate user interactions, and for database object-relational mapping. Wt is available under either the GNU GPL Version 2 license, or a commercial license; commercial licenses were purchased for the SNL developers of InterSpec.
Boost C++ libraries.
InterSpec uses Boost for a host of tasks, including: as a dependancy to Wt, unit testing, mathematical constants and distributions, input parsing, working with date/times, linear algebra, hashing, supplements to the c++ language, and more. Boost is licensed under the Boost Software License.
RapidXml C++ XML Parser.
A slightly modified version of this library, which allows parsing of some non-compliant XML files, is used for all XML parsing tasks within InterSpec; all modifications are included and marked with the source code of InterSpec. RapidXml is licensed under the Boost Software License.
pugixml Light-weight, simple and fast XML parser for C++ with XPath support.
pugixml is used by the spectrum file query tool to parse an XPath query event XML files. pugixml is licensed under the MIT License. (Windows, Linux, macOS builds only)
Minuit2: Minimization Package.
Minuit2 is part Cern's ROOT package, and is used to perform numerical optizations for peak, energy calibration, and shielding/source-activity fitting. Minuit2 is licensed under the LGPL v2.1 License.
Cuba 3.0: a library for multidimensional numerical integration
Cuba is used to perform the numericall integration for self-attenuation sources in the shielding/source tool. Cuba is licensed under the LGPL v3 License.
muparserx 4.0.7: c++ Math Parser Library.
muparserx is used to evaluate user entered detector efficiencies, and to help evaluate expressions for the TerminalWidget (not all builds of InterSpec contain this tool). muparserx is licensed under the BSD License.
Electron: Package based on the Chromium web browser to build cross platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.
Electron is used to display app contents on standalone Windows and Linux versions of InterSpec. Electron is licensed under the MIT License, but libraries it uses may be licensed under other terms; see Electrons git repository for more information.
SQLite: SQL database engine.
SQLite is used to save user preferences and application state. SQLite is Public Domain software.
ROOT: A modular scientific software framework.
InterSpec uses a small amount of code derived from ROOT to calculate the Landau cumulative distribution function, as well some code derived from the ROOT TSpectrum class to estimate the continuum for a spectrum (a depreciated feature); code used is marked and attributed within the InterSpec source code. ROOT is licensed under the LGPL v2.1 License.
jQuery 1.11.1: javascript library.
jQuery is used to help deal with cross-browser idiosyncrasies in the client-side java script. jQuery is licensed under the MIT License.
qTip2 2.2.0: javascript library that provides tooltip and notification tools.
qTip2 is used to help make the content-rich tooltips, as well as the notifications within InterSpec. qTip2 is licensed under the MIT License.
d3.js: a JavaScript charting library.
d3.js powers rendering and interactions of the spectrum chart, gross-count time chart, and decay tool. d3.js is licensed under the BSD License.
jQuery QueryBuilder: jQuery plugin for user friendly query/filter creator.
QueryBuilder is used to construct spectrum file queries. QueryBuilder is MIT licensed javascript library. (Windows, Linux, macOS builds only)
spectrum.js: The No Hassle jQuery Colorpicker.
spectrum.js is select colors throughout InterSpec when a native HTML5 is not used. spectrum.js is MIT licensed javascript library.
Moment.js: Parse, validate, manipulate, and display dates and times in JavaScript.
Moment.js is used to validate date/time input for the spectrum file query tool. Moment.js is MIT licensed javascript library. (Windows, Linux, macOS builds only)
resize-observer-polyfill: A polyfill for the Resize Observer API.
resize-observer-polyfill is used to support the JavaScript ResizeObserver functionality for older browsers that do not natively support API. resize-observer-polyfill is MIT licensed javascript library.
In addition to the many libraries used within InterSpec, many open-source, or publicly available tools and resources are used to develop InterSpec including, but not limited to:
Evaluated Nuclear Structure Data File (ENSDF): used to derive nuclear decay information and gamma cross sections.
Geant4: Used to extract gamma cross section data from ENSDF to a custom format for InterSpec. Also used to validate physics calculations.
A number of build tools, including: CMake, GCC, Clang/LLVM, Microsoft Visual Studio, Python, Ruby, SVN, and many more have been used to develop, compile, link, or otherwise produce InterSpec.
GadrasDRF: used to obtain detector response functions and create simulated data to test against.

Please email bug reports and feature requests interspec@sandia.gov.
Due to funding and personnel availability, support may not be available.
